Grammar: Relative clauses II

Surfing the Internet

Non-defining relative clauses are separated from the rest of the sentence with commas.
When speaking, we pause before and after a non-defining relative clause.
A friend who lives in Spain [k]sent[/k] it to me.
Margaret
marketing department
What's your username?
laptop
Select the words in the correct order.
Right. So I just [k]click[/k] on the link and it will open automatically?
[k]The decision[/k] [k],[/k] [k]which[/k] [k]was made late last night[/k] [k],[/k] [k]will affect[/k] [k]the whole company.[/k]
Send me the link to the website.
To your personal [k]email[/k] address.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
, sent
link
How would you advertise a company?
Miss Sidhu, [k]who[/k] has contributed a lot to the school, will be leaving at the end of this year.
Non-defining relative clauses give extra or additional information:
My sister, who lives in Paris, is a doctor.
[k]The minister,[/k] [k]who[/k] [k]had been going through a difficult time,[/k][k]was told[/k] [k]to take a holiday.[/k]
Defining relative clauses define who or what we are talking about:
Last week you learned about the basic functions of your laptop. Today, you're going to learn how to use the university [k]search engine[/k] for research purposes.
sponsor
website

The reporter, [k]whose[/k] camera was damaged [k], was[/k] covered by insurance.

In non-defining relative clauses we use the following relative pronouns: who - for people which - for things whose - for possessions 'that' is only used in defining relative clauses

A non-defining relative clause gives information about a noun. They can be taken out and the sentence still has meaning:
advertising agency
slogan
The marketing department is going to launch an advertising campaign.
